The Board itself may subsequently alter its decision or the membership in con¬
vention assembled may direct the Board to reverse its decision *
1 appreciate that you felt the decision at Columbus was wrong and, what's more,
contrary to the wishes of members most concerned. I could wish, though, if you felt
compelled to broadcast your disagreement, that it could have been done with prior
knowledge of headquarters. In that way we might have worked out a joint statement
of opposing views so that readers could have a coherent dialogue upon which to make
a judgment The series of alternate releases—of arguments and counter-arguments—
which did take place was rather undignified and certainly caused needless harm with¬
out, I think, achieving any useful purpose.
At the same time though, I recognise that another democratic principle is
freedom of speech. When somebody feels strongly he ought to speak out. In a
democratic organization, there must be opportunity for reporting so that leaders
cannot keep themselves and their acts from scrutiny, nor can we permit the reporting
to be selectively organised so as to put the administration's case in the most favor¬
able light. 1 respect your right to write; 1 just deplore the manner in which you chose,
on this occasion, to exercise it.
At the convention there will be an opportunity for the ETV station managers to
meet and fully express their views and wishes to the Board. You will note that
we have arranged to have the Board meet both at the beginning and end of the con¬
vention so that there will be ample opportunity for the membership to react to initial
proposals and convey wishes to the Board before it fakes final action on any matters
of consequence -
With highest personal regards,
Sincerely,
William G. Harley
